newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Ostend 1996 air cargo boosted by African & CIS trade.
newsitem.headline: Ostend 1996 air cargo boosted by African & CIS trade.

text.p: Growth from the African and ex-Soviet market led to a significant increase in freight volumes handled at Ostend airport, said a spokesman for the airport.
Freight traffic in 1996 rose 12.6 to 91,769 tonnes.
Ethiopian Airlines had increased its flights from twice weekly to daily Boeing 757 flights, he said, with the carrier sometimes leasing in aircraft as well.
Air Memphis and Egyptair were very active, he added, especially during the twice-yearly green bean season from Egypt. Daily flights during the season is not unusual, he added.

The growth was partly due to Belgium's historical links with Africa, he added. Perishable traffic out of African countries was also a reason for the increase in cargo, he said. Electronic goods, general consumer goods and car parts are major shipments into Africa, he added.
Daily flights are also coming into the Belgium airport from many CIS countries, he said. A third of all of the airport's cargo traffic is from CIS countries, said the spokesman.
There had been considerable growth from the many off-shoots of Aeroflot, he said.
